items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water with lake levels peaking around 11:00pm on 07/11/2022. 
Derwentwater lake levels at the Lodore gauge could reach 2m this evening.
We are clearing debris in the area and we will continue to monitor the forecast and issue warnings if necessary.
This message will be updated by 10:00am on 08/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert has now been removed. Due to high spring tides, this alert may need to be re-issued. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River levels are high on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to heavy rainfall this morning, Monday the 07/11/2022.
Areas most at risk include the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel.
River levels are expected to remain high for the next few hours but no flooding to property is expected. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00am on the 08/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 08:15 AM on 07/11/2022.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 08:15 AM and 12:00 PM on 07/11/2022.
We are expecting higher than normal tides up to and including the morning tide of the 9th of November.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 07/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Upper Wey at Standford, Tilford and Godalming areas as a result of persistent heavy rainfall yesterday. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected today and tomorrow 08/11/22.
The forecast for today is for more showers, therefore we expect levels to remain high throughout today and start to drop this afternoon.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated later today 07/11/22, or if the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen following heavy rainfall yesterday, Sunday 6th November 2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast throughout today, Monday 7th November, but we do not expect any further flooding. We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 

Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and taking action where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight this weekend. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected today 07/11/22, especially in the Free Prae Road area. 
The forecast for today is relatively dry with some showers, therefore we expect levels to fall but remain above the threshold for flood alert for the coming days.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated later today, 07/11/22, or if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 09:15 AM on 07/11/2022.
Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 08:30 AM and 10:00 AM on 07/11/2022.
We are expecting higher than normal tides up to and including the morning tide 8th of November 2022.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 07/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Monday evening and Tuesday morning. High water on Monday evening at Exmouth is at 18:15 hours, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 7 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 2m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be up to 390mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level on Monday evening at Exmouth is 2.46 mAOD, this is 0.39 metres above astronomical tide level.

Monday morning's tide at 09:53 on 07/11/2022 and 11:40 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.41 m. The total forecast tide is 4.27 metres Chart Datum (2.27 mAOD) at Beaulieu. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood the garden of the mill house on the downstream side of the Mill Pond. It will also flow across Palace Lane and the B3056 (Hatchet Lane), making it temporarily more difficult for traffic to access the village. Flood water in Palace Lane could be up to 0.2m deep. At 22:06 on Monday (07/11/2022)‚ the tide and flood impacts will be similar to Monday morning. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. For safety, please take care if walking through Beaulieu. The incoming tide will flood roads quickly. At Hatchet Lane, driving through flood water increases flood risk to property. Please avoid using this road. We will update this message by 14:00 on 07/11/2022.

Monday morning's tide at 10:21 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.36 m. The total forecast tide is 5.24 metres Chart Datum (2.51 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, levels will be high at South Street and Queen Street Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park at Langstone will flood. Water will flow into the road at Langstone High Street, although flood depths will be relatively shallow, and flooding will only cause impacts nearest to the harbour front. At 22:34 on Monday (07/11/2022)‚ the tide will be slightly lower than Monday mornings, but impacts will be similar. We'll issue further advice. In Emsworth, we will lower levels in the Mill Pond. If you have it, and live directly on the harbour front, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will update this message by 14:00 on 07/11/2022.

Monday evening's tide at 22:15 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Southerly Force 6 to 7 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.4 m. The total forecast tide is 4.70 metres Chart Datum (2.11 mAOD) at Cowes. For 1 hour either side of high water, large waves will cause spray overtopping and overwashing of defences across the exposed coast at Freshwater Bay, Sandown, Shanklin, Gurnard and Ryde. This will flood esplanades, sea front car parks and roads in seafront locations. As its largely sheltered from wave action, impacts at Cowes will be minimal. The tide will not flood property. At 10:45 tomorrow morning (08/11/22)‚ the forecast tide level will be a little bit higher and may cause minor impact flooding to sea front roads at Yarmouth and Cowes. We continue to monitor the forecast. At high tide, avoid parking, walking or driving at exposed sea front locations. We will update this message by 08:00 on 08/11/2022.

Monday morning's tide at 09:53 on 07/11/2022 and 11:40 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.41 m. The total forecast tide is 5.20 metres Chart Datum (2.46 mAOD) at Southampton. For 1 hour either side of high water, very minor impact flooding will affect the lower floor level of Eling Tide Mill and boat yards at Bursledon. Road and car park flooding may occur at The Quay in Hamble, Magazine Lane at Marchwood and Shore Road in Hythe. At 22:06 on Monday (07/11/2022)‚ the tide and flood impacts will be similar to Monday morning. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid parking in low lying coastal car parks and plan driving routes to avoid the roads listed in this message. We will update this message by 14:00 on 07/11/2022.

Monday morning's tide at 09:53 on 07/11/2022 and 11:40 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.41 m. The total forecast tide is 5.20 metres Chart Datum (2.46 mAOD) at Southampton. For 1.5 hours either side of high water, levels in the lower River Itchen will increase as the incoming tide prevents water from flowing out to sea. Footpath flooding will affect some areas of Riverside Park. The pub car park at Mansbridge, may see minor impact flooding for a short period of time. Any flood depth would be relatively shallow. The tide will not flood property or the A27. At 22:06 on Monday (07/11/2022)‚ the tide and flood impacts will be similar to Monday morning. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. As a very precautionary measure, please consider closing the defence gates around the pub. We will update this message by 14:00 on 07/11/2022.

River levels are still higher than normal in Isfield, but all along the River Uck water levels are now falling and are significantly lower than recent days. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads could continue until Monday afternoon, when the River Uck should be nearer to normal. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 07/11/2022.

items.message:
Following further heavy rainfall yesterday, river levels remain high but are falling gradually at Forest Row, Summerford Bridge, near Withyham and at Colliers land Bridge near Ashurst. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is forecast today, Monday 7 November 2022, but no further river level rise is expected. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly around Forest Row, Ashurst and Penshurst and around Balls Green at Ashurst. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Monday 7 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.  
Further light rainfall is expected today 07/11/2022, however this is not expected to cause any further flooding. We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this flood alert if required.

items.description: River Teise area from Lamberhurst to Goudhurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  

Light showers are forecast today, Monday 7 November 2022 with no further rise expected. We will continue to monitor the situation.  

Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

The River Adur is still very high but is now slowly falling. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and riverside properties at Mock Bridge near Shermanbury. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. On the River Adur, levels are unlikely to return to nearer normal until Tuesday afternoon (08/11/2022). Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable.  Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on Monday 07/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar remains very high. At Alverstone, the level is now slowly falling. This follows a night of mostly dry weather. Out of bank flooding affecting gardens, roads and access tracks is expected in the Upper Yar Valley throughout today (07/11/22). At Sandown, the level is slowly rising. Minor flood impacts will be affecting Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain. From 13:30 this afternoon (07/11/22), the river could come close to flooding the bottom of gardens at Sandown Bridge. Land at River Park Caravan Park may be flooded. The level at Sandown will not peak until around 16:00 this afternoon. From today (Monday 07/11/22) until Wednesday (09/11/22), showers are forecast. During this time, we expect the river to continue falling, but it will remain very sensitive to further rain. We are operating Bembridge sluice to manage levels across Brading marshes. Please ensure products used to protect gardens and property are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 07/11/22.

The River Ouse is still very high but has just started to slowly fall in Barcombe. Flooding will continue to affect properties at Barcombe Mills, and fields, gardens and rural roads along most of the Upper Ouse. Including at Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. Barcombe Mills Road will be impassable. River levels nearer Ardingly have already fallen significantly from their peak. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. It is likely to be Tuesday afternoon (08/11/2022) before river levels return nearer to normal, perhaps midweek in Barcombe. Some roads are likely to be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road and at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 07/11/2022.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no significant rainfall overnight into tomorrow, but showers will continue into next week. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

The Cuckmere River in Alfriston is still very high and currently rising. Flooding will continue to affect locations near North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. River levels should begin to slowly fall in Alfriston from 11:00 Monday 07/11/2022, but will remain higher than normal until at least midweek. The Bull River in Hellingly is still very high but is now slowly falling. Minor flood impacts affecting properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road Hellingly are likely to continue until Monday evening. The Cuckmere River through Hellingly has already fallen significantly from its peak and only minor impacts are expected at Mill Lane, Hellingly. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding in Hellingly and Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 07/11/2022.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Following further heavy rainfall yesterday, River levels remain high at locations in the Rother valley. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is forecast today, Monday 7 November 2022, but no further river level rise is expected. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly in the Crowhurst Bridge area, around Shrub Lane and along the River Rother, particularly around Robertsbridge. We are ready to use the flood defence scheme at Robertsbridge if required. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation, and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Monday 7 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high in the Leatherhead and Cobham areas. The risk of flooding to roads and low lying land remains throughout today 7/11/2022. Further light rainfall is expected today. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please remain aware of your local situation. This message will be updated by 10:00am on Tuesday 8/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: The River Adur is still very high but is now slowly falling. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and riverside properties at Mock Bridge near Shermanbury. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. On the River Adur, levels are unlikely to return to nearer normal until Tuesday afternoon (08/11/2022). Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable.  Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on Monday 07/11/2022.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely for the rest of today and into the evening. The River Wid has risen steadily in response to recent heavy rainfall, but has now stabilised, and levels will slowly drop back over the course of the day. Areas most at risk are low-lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. The weather forecast is for light rain and strong winds through today. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 4pm today, Monday 7th November.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Following further heavy rainfall yesterday, river levels remain high but are falling gradually at locations between Yalding and Allington Lock, including Maidstone. Internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is forecast today, Monday 7 November 2022, but no further river level rise is expected. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly riverside areas of Maidstone and along the River Medway. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Monday 7 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

The Bull River in Hellingly is still very high but is now slowly falling. Minor flood impacts affecting properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly are likely to continue until Monday evening. The Cuckmere River through Hellingly has already fallen significantly from its peak, only minor impacts are expected at Mill Lane, Hellingly. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. The Bull River might not return to nearer a normal level until Tuesday afternoon (08/11/2022). Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Station Road, Church Lane, Church Road and Mill Lane, Hellingly. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 07/11/2022.

The River Ouse is still very high, but has just started to slowly fall in Barcombe. Flooding will continue to affect properties at Barcombe Mills and the Anchor Inn. Impacting fields, gardens and rural roads along most of the Upper Ouse. Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane will be impassable. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. It could be midweek before river levels return nearer to normal in Barcombe. Some roads may be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Please keep flood protection products installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 07/11/2022.

The Cuckmere River in Alfriston is still very high and currently rising. Flooding will continue to affect locations near North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Access along Litlington Road may be restricted by flood water. River levels should begin to slowly fall in Alfriston from 11:00 Monday 07/11/2022, but will remain higher than normal until at least midweek. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. We will continue to monitor the levels and forecast and will share further information if the risk of flooding increases again. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 07/11/2022.

items.message:
Following further heavy rainfall yesterday, river levels remain high but are falling gradually in Edenbridge, Hever, Vexour,  Lingfield and Haxted Mill areas. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is forecast today, Monday 7 November 2022 but no further river level rise is expected. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Monday 7 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Scrase Bridge and West Common Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Scrase Bridge Stream, West Common Stream

items.message: The Scrasebridge and West Common Streams are now falling following Sunday’s rainfall. Minor flood impacts should have reduced at Meadow Drive, Bridge Road, West Common Road, Hickmans Lane and Blackthorns this afternoon. Most of the rain has now cleared, but isolated showers are possible Sunday evening, continuing Monday and Tuesday, which could see river levels rise again. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We routinely clear debris from grilles through Lindfield, including the Builders Centre and Witch Inn, to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases significantly.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high in in Cranleigh as a result of persistent heavy rainfall yesterday. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland remains possible today 07/11/22.
The forecast for today is drier, and we expect levels to start to drop slowly.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this afternoon 07/11/22, or if the situation changes.

items.message: The river levels on the Ravensbourne peaked this morning at 11am and have now fallen. Although the river levels are still high the risk of flooding has now passed. Further rainfall is expected over the next 36 hours however, it is not expected to cause any significant flooding and we will update this message if the forecast or situation changes significantly.

items.description: River Ingrebourne at Harold Park and Hornchurch
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen following heavy rainfall yesterday, Sunday 6th November 2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast throughout today, Monday 7th November, but we do not expect any further flooding. We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 

Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and taking action where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

items.description: River Darent from Westerham to Dartford
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.  
Further light rainfall is expected today 07/11/2022, however this is not expected to cause any further flooding. We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this flood alert if required.

The Western Rother is still very high, and slowly rising at Fittleworth. River levels in Fittleworth are likely to continue rising until Monday evening. By 16:00 Monday 07/11/2022, water could be very close to Fittleworth Mill and nearby properties. At Lodsbridge near Selham the river is very high, but now slowly falling. Water will be very close to properties at Lodsbridge until Tuesday. Between Liss and Midhurst, river levels have already fallen significantly from their peak, and only minor flood impacts are expected. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. The river will be higher than normal at Fittleworth most of the week. Please keep property flood resilience measures installed at Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 07/11/2022.

Most of the rain has now cleared to the east. Isolated showers are possible Sunday evening, Monday and Tuesday, however hopefully not enough rain to cause river levels to rise significantly. The Langney Haven should now slowly fall over the next few days, but is unlikely to return to normal until the end of the week. There is still uncertainty in the weather forecast, so please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again in the coming days. We continue to operate our structures at Fence Bridge to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding significantly increases.

The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven remain high following Sunday’s rain. River levels have been slowly falling in Crowhurst, but scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. One shower has recently caused a small increase in river level. If a shower in the Crowhurst area is particularly intense, flood water could possibly approach a small number of riverside properties in Crowhurst on Forewood Lane and between the Plough public house and Sandrock Hill. However, we feel it is more likely the river should slowly fall Monday afternoon, with river levels in Crowhurst returning nearer to normal by Tuesday afternoon. River levels in Bulverhythe could stay higher than normal until the end of the week, but only minor flood impacts affecting Bexhill Road Recreation Ground are currently predicted. Please keep flood protection products installed in Crowhurst, if you have them, as a precaution. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 07/11/2022.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Monday morning's tide at 10:30 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 7 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.22 m. The total forecast tide is 6.16 metres Chart Datum (3.11 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Very similar tide, weather and flood impact conditions are forecast each tide through to Wednesday morning 09/11/2022. This may cause minor impacts at each high water. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Avoid walking at the sea front or parking at Climping Street Car Park. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/11/2022.

The River Arun is still high and slowly rising, at Newbridge near Billingshurst and Pallingham Lock. River levels might not begin to fall at Pallingham Lock until Tuesday (08/11/2022). River levels are now slowly falling between Horsham and Wanford. However, all along the Upper Arun, minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens, rural roads and approaching riverside and mill properties, will continue. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Please keep flood protection products installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 21:00 07/11/2022.

River levels are high but steady on the on the River Roding in Abridge, Buckhurst Hill and Loughton because of persistent heavy rainfall yesterday, Sunday 6 November. The risk of flooding to roads and low lying land remains due to high river levels. 
Further light rainfall is forecast today, Monday 7 November but we do not expect river levels to rise much further. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and remain aware of the weather forecast. 

This message will be updated by 5pm on Monday 7 November, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady on the on the River Roding in the Molehill Green, Dunmow, Ongar, Fyfield, High Ongar and Stapleford areas because of persistent heavy rainfall yesterday, Sunday 6 November. The risk of flooding to roads and low-lying land remains due to high river levels. 
Further light rainfall is forecast today, Monday 7 November but we do not expect river levels to rise much further. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and remain aware of the weather forecast. 

This message will be updated by 5pm on Monday 7 November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Cripsey Brook in Epping Forest District Council
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen following heavy rainfall yesterday, Sunday 6th November 2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast throughout today, Monday 7th November, but we do not expect any further flooding. We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 

Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and taking action where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

The River Lox is still high, but is now slowly falling. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens along the length of the river Lox and be near properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. The river should return to nearer normal by Tuesday afternoon. However, scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Please continue to operate private water control structures in Brewhurst, to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 07/11/2022.

items.description: Whitwell, Wroxall, Langbridge, Alverstone on the Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar at Alverstone remains very high but is now slowly falling. This follows a night of mostly dry weather. In Langbridge, Horringford and Alverstone, out of bank flooding affecting gardens, roads and access tracks is expected to continue over the next 18 hours. Golf Links Road will remain impassable today (07/11/2022). From today (Monday 07/11/2022) until Wednesday (09/11/2022), showers are forecast. During this time, we expect the river level to continue falling, but it will remain very sensitive to further rainfall, and could begin to rise again if heavier rain affects the area. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river is kept free of any reported blockages. Please ensure products used to protect gardens and property are operating. This Flood Warning will be updated or removed by 18:00 on Monday 07/11/2022.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the Hoe Stream as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of property/roads and farmland is expected this morning, 07/11/22, especially in the Mayford area. We do not forecast the situation to deteriorate any further.
Lighter rain is forecast today or tomorrow, therefore levels should start to fall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area checking defences. 
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. 
This message will be updated later today 07/11/22, or if the situation changes.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely over the next few hours and into this evening, Monday 7th November. The River Colne is rising steadily in response to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying land and riverside areas around Great Yeldham, Castle Hedingham, Sible Hedingham, Halstead, White Colne, Chappel, Fordstreet, and the Toppesfield Brook, and in Colchester between the A12 and East Street. Further rain is expected to move across the country overnight tonight, and heavy blustery showers are expected tomorrow. The forecast is for drier conditions on Wednesday and Thursday. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Monday 7th November.

The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes are high and rising. In the last week, more than a month's rain (100mm) has been recorded at Westergate. Heavy showers Monday morning, mean from 13:00 07/11/2022 flood water could affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, and possibly parts of the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road. Minor flood impacts could affect land at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Only minimal or minor flood impacts are currently expected in Barnham. Potentially affecting riverside properties in Marshall Close, and along Lake Lane and Barnham Road, Barnham. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. In Bersted the river should begin to fall by 20:00 07/11/2022, but will be higher than normal all week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barnham, if you have them, as a precaution. Our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 22:00 07/11/2022.

items.description: South Devon coast from Dawlish Warren to Seaton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Monday evening. High water at Exmouth is at 18:15 hours, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 7 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of 2m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 390mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Exmouth is 2.46 mAOD, this is 0.39 metres above astronomical tide level.
